Title.evidence: METHODS:: A pragmatic randomized, controlled, pivotal trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Subjects had Visual Analog Scale scores of ≥5.0/10.0 cm for both back and leg pain, and were assigned randomly (1:1)

Participants.evidence: Subjects had Visual Analog Scale scores of ≥5.0/10.0 cm for both back and leg pain, and were assigned randomly (1:1) to receive HF10 therapy or low-frequency SCS.

Intervention.evidence: assigned randomly (1:1) to receive HF10 therapy or low-frequency SCS.

Objective.evidence: OBJECTIVE:: To compare long-term results of HF10 therapy and traditional low-frequency SCS.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary end point was a responder rate, defined as ≥50% back pain reduction from baseline at 3 months

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Subjects had Visual Analog Scale scores of ≥5.0/10.0 cm for both back and leg pain, and were assigned randomly (1:1)

Number_Randomised.evidence: In the study, 198 subjects were randomized (101 HF10 therapy, 97 traditional SCS).

Number_Analysed.evidence: One hundred seventy-one subjects (90 HF10 therapy, 81 traditional SCS) successfully completed a short-term trial and were implanted.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 24 months, more subjects were responders to HF10 therapy than traditional SCS (back pain: 76.5% vs 49.3%; 27.2% difference, 95% CI, 10.1%-41.8%; P < .001 for non-inferiority and superiority; leg pain: 72.9% vs 49.3%; 23.6% difference, 95% CI, 5.9%-38.6%; P < .001 for non-inferiority and P = .003 for superiority).
